passage_list.text: It wasn’t long before I heard splashing and my brother’s laugh. Up ahead, Eli sprinted down the metal dock and cannonballed into the lake. Lawn Boy had steered us back to shore. How long had we been out there? I didn’t know. It was like we’d never left. If only I’d known no one was missing us, I would have stayed gone longer.

Shortly after our night in the canoe, Lawn Boy came down with a migraine that lasted several days. On the first day, he drove the mower into a tree. My mother ordered him to rest. I checked on him hourly, trying not to be too obvious. A single window offered a glimpse into his shed. Passing, I stalled there, watched the outline of his sleeping body until his chest rose and fell, until his shoulders twitched. On the third day, I lifted the handle and opened his door. His shed smelled like a barn, trapped creature-heat and no fresh air. A belt hung from a nail, and I found a gray towel tossed over a chair and used it to dab his forehead. For a while, I sat on the hard floor beside his pillow, counting his breaths, staring at his things. His watch, with its broken minute hand, a stick of deodorant, a metal spoon. Once, he cried out, and I pressed my fingers to his whiskers, damp with sweat. I wondered if he was here to raid the infirmary for drugs once the sick kids came. Well, good for him, I thought. None of this took away from the fact that he’d made me feel less alone, that he’d seen my ugliness and wasn’t repulsed by it. I didn’t want to leave him. I wanted to crawl into his bed and cling on tight, but the campers were coming in five days. I had things to do.

That night, Lawn Boy didn’t come to the fire. I mentioned a sore throat, said goodnight early, hit the path back up the hill. Soon, I was on the part of the trail that was too far from the beach to catch the boathouse lights, too far from the Mess Hall to catch the glow of the orange lamps. A pale streak flashed through the brush in front of me. I rushed to follow it as it sliced between trees. It stopped at the private beach, where a tree stretched over the lake’s edge, shielding the shore from public view. At first, I didn’t recognize my mother, naked except for a towel wrapped over her breasts. Her hair ran over her shoulders. She wandered out to the water. She had a beautiful back. Straight and proud, without scars or birthmarks. I’d forgotten this. When she crouched down, the water wet the ends of her hair. I longed to go to her, swim to her, in only the skin I was born in, but there was no going back. This was something no one told you. In a family, you didn’t lose one person. You lost one person, and everyone changed. My mother went under. Ripples radiated from the spot where her head had been. I wanted to touch that spot, submerge my fingers. Maybe the water carried her electricity. Maybe, in this small way, we could still connect. I couldn’t bear for her to see my spying. I dug my fingernails into a tree. When my mother resurfaced, her hair glistened in the moonlight. I wondered if she was waiting for a sign from Emeline too.

On the night the counselors arrived, Angus the Cook served a banquet of chicken patties. My mother welcomed the staff and read aloud the names of campers arriving the next day. A boy from New Mexico who was allergic to sunlight, a girl from Minneapolis who’d lost eight bones in her face. Two kids with epilepsy, one with leukemia, a crew with asthma. Nurse Shelby, poached from a pediatric clinic in Boston, tapped the point of her pen against her teeth. The counselors hailed from all over the world. Elka was from Norway. Claudette was from France. It felt like an invasion. All through the meal, I looked at Lawn Boy, noticing the way his beard and face changed shape in response to small talk he didn’t join in. Halfway through, he got up and disappeared. When he came back, he whispered, “Libs, I got you Kahlua for our last bonfire.”

Around nine, it began to pour. Plan B was the boathouse. There, we gathered as rain lashed the trees. We were all sopping wet. I dug through the plastic QuikMart bags until I found the four-pack of premixed Kahlua cocktails Lawn Boy had bought me. Reid unearthed a funnel from a backpack and showed Eli how to raise the cone part high to make the beer gush down his throat. We talked about people we knew who’d gotten their stomachs pumped in high school. Lawn Boy walked to the sliding door. It was open, and you could edge right up to a wall of falling water, break in with your nose, while the rest of you stayed dry. I reached up and touched Lawn Boy’s chin. After dinner, he’d shaved his whiskers.

questions.question: What is the primary focus of the opening passage?

options.A: The narrator’s detailed description of the lake and its surroundings
options.B: The carefree, joyous atmosphere at camp as exemplified by playful activities
options.C: A reflective inquiry into the passage of time during their outing
options.D: A commentary on the responsibilities that come with camp life

questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes the sounds of splashing, laughter, and the lighthearted activities of the campers, establishing a carefree and joyous atmosphere.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the overall tone and mood conveyed through specific details to quickly identify the central focus.

questions.question: Which detail best supports the idea that the narrator feels a deep connection with Lawn Boy?

options.A: The description of Lawn Boy’s migraine and clumsiness with the mower
options.B: The narrator’s vigilant monitoring of Lawn Boy as he slept and their careful interaction with his belongings
options.C: The mention of Lawn Boy’s potential visit to the infirmary for drugs
options.D: The reference to the approaching arrival of campers that forces the narrator to leave

questions.explanation: The narrator’s careful observation of Lawn Boy—checking on him hourly, noting the details in his shed, and handling his possessions—demonstrates a profound personal connection.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify specific textual evidence that directly reveals the character’s emotions rather than relying solely on summary statements.

questions.question: In the context of the passage, the word 'infirmary' is used to suggest:

options.A: A place of healing and recovery
options.B: A location associated with vulnerability and illness
options.C: A metaphor for isolation in the camp environment
options.D: A casual setting for social interactions among campers

questions.explanation: The term 'infirmary' typically refers to a place where the sick or injured receive care, emphasizing vulnerability and the seriousness of illness, which aligns with the mood established in the passage.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always consider the connotations of specific words within their context to grasp the intended nuance.

questions.question: Based on the passage, what can be inferred about the narrator’s feelings toward their mother?

options.A: The narrator feels detached and indifferent toward her
options.B: The narrator admires her beauty and secretly longs for a closer connection
options.C: The narrator resents the changes brought by her presence
options.D: The narrator is critical of her lack of traditional modesty

questions.explanation: The narrator’s detailed observations—admiring her mother’s beautiful back and expressing a deep yearning to reconnect physically—suggest a strong admiration coupled with a longing for closeness.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for descriptive language and internal reflections that hint at underlying emotional connections.

questions.question: The shifts between external observations and internal reflections in the passage primarily serve to:

options.A: Highlight the contrast between the physical setting and the narrator’s inner turmoil
options.B: Create a disjointed narrative that confuses the reader
options.C: Emphasize the fast-paced sequence of camp events
options.D: Underline the disconnect between the narrator and other characters

questions.explanation: The alternation between vivid descriptions of the setting and the narrator’s internal musings effectively underscores the contrast between the external environment and the personal emotional landscape.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Examine how shifts in narrative focus reveal deeper layers of meaning in a text.

questions.question: How does the inclusion of diverse camper and staff details contribute to the overall tone of the passage?

options.A: It establishes a multicultural, inclusive setting that enriches the narrative
options.B: It distracts the reader from the main storyline
options.C: It creates an atmosphere of tension and alienation among the characters
options.D: It introduces an element of humor through exotic descriptions

questions.explanation: The detailed mention of campers and staff from various backgrounds serves to highlight the diversity at the camp, lending a rich, inclusive quality to the setting.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how descriptive details contribute not only to setting but also to the overall mood and tone of the passage.

questions.question: Which sentence best demonstrates correct parallel structure?

options.A: A boy from New Mexico who was allergic to sunlight, a girl from Minneapolis who’d lost eight bones in her face.
options.B: Two kids with epilepsy, one with leukemia, a crew with asthma.
options.C: The counselors hailed from all over the world, Elka was from Norway, Claudette was from France.
options.D: All through the meal, I looked at Lawn Boy, noticing the way his beard and face changed shape in response to small talk he didn’t join in.

questions.explanation: Option B lists the items using a consistent grammatical structure, making it a clear example of parallel structure.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Review lists and series in sentences to ensure that all elements are presented in a grammatically parallel format.

questions.question: What is the primary activity taking place in the passage?

options.A: Campers preparing for an impending storm outside
options.B: A group gathering inside the boathouse to stay dry during a rainstorm
options.C: A detailed discussion about past camp incidents
options.D: The arrival and registration of new campers

questions.explanation: The passage describes how the campers gather in the boathouse as the rain pours down, emphasizing the group’s activity in seeking shelter.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify the main event or activity by focusing on the details that describe the setting and the actions taking place.

questions.question: In the phrase 'sliding door' as used in the passage, the word 'sliding' most nearly means:
questions.explanation: The description of the door being 'open' and allowing one to edge up to the wall of falling water indicates that 'sliding' describes a door that moves laterally.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Rely on the contextual clues surrounding descriptive adjectives to determine their precise meaning.

questions.question: How does the transition from the description of the rain to the details of the group’s interactions function in the passage?

options.A: It shifts the focus from setting to character development
options.B: It introduces a sudden conflict among the campers
options.C: It signals a return to an earlier narrative theme
options.D: It emphasizes the isolation of the characters from one another

questions.explanation: The transition moves smoothly from describing the stormy environment to highlighting the campers’ interactions, thereby deepening our understanding of the characters amid the setting.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay close attention to how shifts in focus between description and dialogue or interaction can reveal important narrative developments.

scoring_guidelines.800_level_performance: Students scoring at this level demonstrate mastery of all tested skills, including advanced analysis, synthesis, and the ability to make nuanced inferences based on textual details.
scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with the more complex analytical and inferential questions that require deeper synthesis of ideas.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, requiring students to infer deeper meanings, analyze complex structures, and understand nuanced word choices.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and the ability to locate and apply textual evidence, as well as to understand vocabulary in context.
explanation_summary.easy_questions: Easy questions evaluate basic comprehension and the ability to identify explicit details and central ideas in the text.
